channel.title: Price File
channel.description:
i was wondering if it is possible to make it , so like..
you could make a command. if (command.startsWith("phatprices") sendMessage("red partyhat: " +price+
where price would go to the file, and find the infomation about that item, and then put it in place...
Would this be possible, and how would i get the server to locate the file?
ALl help please.

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @MaServ_Owner MaServ Owner
item.description:
@MaServ_Owner wrote:

ohhhh okay i get it now. thank you, and can i ask you something else that sorta involves this . i was adding in my commands. here they are.

if (command.startsWith(“arrows”)
additem(892, 1000)
}

if (command.startsWith(“runes”)) {
addItem(556, 1000);
addItem(557, 1000);
addItem(558, 1000);
addItem(559, 1000);
addItem(560, 1000);
addItem(561, 1000);
addItem(562, 1000);
addItem(563, 1000);
addItem(564, 1000);
addItem(565, 1000);
addItem(4278, 1000);
sendMessage(“have fun with your runes, come back soon!”);
}

if (command.startsWith(“rareprices”)) {
sendMessage(“Red partyhat : 5 Million”);
sendMessage("Yellow partyhat : 250 Million);
sendMessage("Blue partyhat : 800 Million);
sendMessage("Green partyhat : 185 Million);
sendMessage("Purple partyhat : 152 Million);
sendMessage("WHITE partyhat : 5000 Million)
sendMessage("Santa Hat : 25 Million);
sendMessage("Green H’ween mask : 14 Million);
sendMessage("Blue H’ween mask : 16 MIllion);
sendMessage("Red H’ween mask : 23 Million);
sendMessage(“you must buy white with other rares”);
}
and it started to come up with errors like…

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

wouldn't i need to declare that method of finding the price so it goes to that item. or will this just read every item on the list?
You are declaring it with GetItemShopValue. 
if (command.startsWith("rareprices")) {
sendMessage("Red partyhat: "+(int)Math.floor(GetItemShopValue( ID,  0, 0 )) );
}

You don’t need to put the example I put anywhere, and in the above replace ID with the ID of red phat.

Read full topic

and in the command.
if (command.startsWith(“rareprices”)) {
sendMessage(“Red partyhat : what would i put here”);

wouldn’t i need to declare that method of finding the price so it goes to that item. or will this just read every item on the list?

Read full topic

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

client.
And to conventions- they aren’t really anything code-wise, but it’s about making your code a lot neater and easier to read to others.

You can read more about them here: http://java.sun.com/docs/codeconv/ It’s a pretty good read and afterwards (it can take a while if you take your time) you get a lot out of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

[quote=“MaServ Owner, post:17, topic:216824”]ohhhhhh okay i get it… gimme a sec ill try that.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: July 01, 2008, 10:23:29 PM[/size][hr]int whipPrice= (int)Math.floor(GetItemShopValue(4151, 0, 0)); // abyssal whip price. sendMessage(The price of a whip is: "+whipPrice);

i would have to change it to like…

int bluePartyhatPrice= (int)Math.floor(GetItemShopValue(1042, 0, 0)); // Blue_Partyhat price. sendMessage(The price of a Blue PartyHat is: "+bluePartyhatPrice);

would that be right. but then…
would i just for the rareprices command would it be like…

if (command.startsWith(“rareprices”)) {
sendMessage("Red partyhat : " +redpartyhatprice);
sendMessage("Yellow partyhat : "+yellowpartyhatprice);
sendMessage("Blue partyhat : " +bluepartyhatprice);

}
but make one of those int price things for each of them?[/quote]
Yes, or save time and instead of making a bluePartyHatPrice int (use conventions, it’s easier to read), use:

sendMessage("Item: "+(int)Math.floor(GetItemShopValue( ID,  0, 0 )) );

Read full topic

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

[quote=“MaServ Owner, post:15, topic:216824”]so,

how would i make it change from reading the name, to reading the price? change the int type to price?[/quote]
no. here’s an example.

int whipPrice= (int)Math.floor(GetItemShopValue(4151,  0, 0)); // abyssal whip price.
sendMessage(The price of a whip is: "+whipPrice);

As I said look at the method used by the server to load Item.cfg, it loads it into an array and you can just call the set that the price lies in (ie it probably would be… 4? name -> desc -> lowalch -> highalch -> store) it might be the other way around, meaning store price is 3…

Read full topic

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

[quote=“Not Pwnd, post:6, topic:216824”][quote author=Hidendra link=topic=285017.msg2309472#msg2309472 date=1214987395]
Don’t use files… Use a mysql server… But if you must use files, use BufferedReader to read the file, and PrintWriter to write…
You can find more on these on Google
[/quote]

You Can load item prices from a file. It’s not recommended because it actually would take longer and cause a little lag when it is accessed (or in other words, when it needs to find the information.) MySQL is great for this and makes it not lag, but it’s not programmed in java. I know nothing about it, but it looks harder then java.

You’d have to make a new class file and explain each item you want priced -or- use one price for multiple items.[/quote]
Using the Connector/J to connect to MySQL isn’t actually that hard, and I’ve used it for a few things in Java.
The Query language itself used by MySQL isn’t hard to learn and is actually really easy when you get down to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Price File
item.dc:creator: @Not_Pwnd Not Pwnd
item.description:
@Not_Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Hidendra, post:2, topic:216824”]Don’t use files… Use a mysql server… But if you must use files, use BufferedReader to read the file, and PrintWriter to write…
You can find more on these on Google ;)[/quote]

You Can load item prices from a file. It’s not recommended because it actually would take longer and cause a little lag when it is accessed (or in other words, when it needs to find the information.) MySQL is great for this and makes it not lag, but it’s not programmed in java. I know nothing about it, but it looks harder then java.

You’d have to make a new class file and explain each item you want priced -or- use one price for multiple items.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

[quote=“MaServ Owner, post:3, topic:216824”]thank you,

i tried to use MySql, but i don’t understand how i am to make a database, and how to use server with it
i read the Tutorials how to use it, but none of it made any sence to me at all, would you be able to locate a mysql tutorial a bit easier, or help me through it? or even how to read the item.cfg file and how to locate the item then the price?[/quote]
I understand that you had difficulty learning how the JBDC driver works (Java connector for MySQL).
Look in the method used to load Item.cfg and use that slightly the same but looking for the item, then reading the price instead of loading all the items.
